prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Field 1 - C18O(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The first field in our proposed survey of AGB stars, consisting of 3 C- and 1 M-type sources. For GX Mon we have previously been able to calculate a 17O/18O ratio using single-dish data. However, the greatly increased SNR obtainable with ALMA will allow us to validate this previous result.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have estimated the spectral line strengths of the C17O(2-1) and C18O(2-1) lines based on: 1) previously obtained CO line strengths from large scale surveys (when available), or 2) an empirical relation from these surveys between the IRAS 60 micron flux and the CO(2-1) line flux. In both cases we have rescaled the flux to the ALMA synthesized beam size with our selected resolution. For the conversion to C17O and C18O line strengths we have used an upper limit for the 16O/17O and 16O/18O ratios, thus putting a lower limit on the expected line strengths. A SNR of at least 3 is thus expected using a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam RMS. The continuum flux was estimated by extrapolating the SED acquired from photometry measurement and rescaling to the ALMA synthesized beam size. As the lines are typically at least 20-30 km/s wide, we have opted for a velocity resolution of 2 km/s for the sensitivity calculations. This will allow us to perform an accurate radiative transfer analysis with over 10 spectral resolution elements per line width for even the weakest lines.

In order to further decrease the total overhead, a common velocity for all sources was selected. Thus we opted for the best possible spectral resolution while still guaranteeing that the line will be located in the spectral window of ~300 km/s. Spectral averaging with a factor of 2 was selected in order to lower the data rate.
The LO frequency was carefully chosen as to be able to include additional molecular lines (CO, 13CO, SiO and SiS) which will greatly assist in the modeling/analysis.

We have chosen the largest angular resolution obtainable for all of our proposed science goals as this will limit the required integration times while also minimizing the chances of possibly resolving out flux. For the most extended of the proposed targets, the flux might be expected to slightly exceed the maximum recoverable scale. We thus elect to also propose for complementary ACA observations, to ensure no loss of flux.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The fourth and final field in our proposed survey of AGB stars, consisting of 2 C- and 3 M-type sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have estimated the spectral line strengths of the C17O(2-1) and C18O(2-1) lines based on: 1) previously obtained CO line strengths from large scale surveys (when available), or 2) an empirical relation from these surveys between the IRAS 60 micron flux and the CO(2-1) line flux. A SNR of at least 3 is thus expected using a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam RMS. The continuum flux was estimated by extrapolating the SED acquired from photometry measurement and rescaling to the ALMA synthesized beam size. As the lines are typically at least 20-30 km/s wide, we have opted for a velocity resolution of 2 km/s for the sensitivity calculations. This will allow us to perform an accurate radiative transfer analysis with over 10 spectral resolution elements per line width for even the weakest lines.

We thus elect to also propose for complementary ACA observations, to ensure no loss of flux.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Isotope ratios are by far the best tracers for the efficiency of the nucleosynthetic and dredge-up (DU) processes as they are very sensitive to the precise conditions in the nuclear burning regions. Isotopologues are hence the key to understanding the stellar origin of elements. However, observed isotopic fractions for asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars are very scarce. We propose to determine the isotopic ratios of O, being crucial tracers of the poorly constrained extra-mixing processes in stellar atmospheres, for 17 AGB stars with different chemical types to complement our observations already obtained. By deriving the 17O/18O isotopic abundance fractions from these stars we will (1) give direct constraints on stellar evolution models. Contrarily assuming validity of current models, we can (2) provide an accurate determination of the stellar initial mass.
